case_data.name: Do No Harm v. David Geffen School of Medicine at UCLA
case_data.summary: (This summary is temporary while we research the case further). On May 8, 2025, Do No Harm sued the UCLA medical school for allegedly employing a race-based admissions process.

1  NATURE OF ACTION 
1.  PlaintiffsDo No Harm; Students for Fair Admissions; and Kelly Ma-
2 
3  honey, individually and on behalf of all others similarly situatedbring this civil action 
4 
under the Equal Protection Clause of the Fourteenth Amendment, Title IV of the Civil 
5 
Rights Act of 1964, 42 U.S.C. 1981, and the Unruh Civil Rights Act to stop the David 
6 
7  Geffen School of Medicine at UCLA and various UCLA officials from engaging in 
8 
intentional discrimination on the basis of race and ethnicity in the admissions process.  
9 
2.  In 2023, the U.S. Supreme Court reminded universities what has always 
10 
11  been true: Racial discrimination is invidious in all contexts. SFFA v. Harvard, 600 
12 
U.S. 181, 214 (2023) (cleaned up). The right to public education must be made avail-
13 
able to all on equal terms without regard to race. Id. at 204 (quoting Brown v. Bd. of 
14 
15  Educ., 493 U.S. 483, 493 (1954)). Race-based admissions demean[] the dignity and 
16 
worth of a person by judging them by ancestry instead of by his or her own merit 
17 
and essential qualities. Id. at 220 (cleaned up). The U.S. Constitution prohibits public 
18 
universities from using race as a factor in affording educational opportunities. Id. at 
19 
20 
204.   
21 
3.  But UCLA didnt need that reminder. Long before Harvard, the people 
22 
of California passed Proposition 209, which banned the consideration of race in uni-
23 
24  versity admissions. The California Constitution now unambiguously states: The State 
25 
shall not discriminate against, or grant preferential treatment to, any individual or 
26 
27 
28 
  3 
 

Case 2:25-cv-04131     Document 1     Filed 05/08/25     Page 4 of 38   Page ID #:4
 
1  group on the basis of race  in the operation of  public education. Cal. Const. art. 
2 
I, 31(a).   
3 
4.  But Californias universities have never liked Prop 209, at least the part 
4 
5  that bans them from giving admissions preferences to blacks. The University of Cali-
6 
fornia System has campaigned for Prop 209s repeal. And behind the scenes, its admis-
7 
sions offices have reintroduced the intentional consideration of race.     
8 
5.  Indeed, the UC Systems illegal use of race is currently being challenged 
9 
10 
in another case pending before this Court. Students Against Racial Discrimination v. Regents 
11 
of the Univ. of Cal., No. 8:25-cv-192-JWH-JDE (C.D. Cal.). 
12 
6.  UCLAs medical school has adopted an Anti-Racism Roadmap, under 
13 
14  which it racially balances its medical-student population.  
15 
7.  Consistent with its racial goals, Geffen made Jennifer Lucero dean of ad-
16 
missions in 2020. Lucero is an outspoken advocate for using race to make admission 
17 
18  and hiring decisions in medical schools and hospitals. As dean of admissions, Lucero 
19 
wields significant influence over Geffens admissions policies and practices, the ap-
20 
pointment of the admissions committee members, the committees deliberations, and 
21 
22  admission decisions.  
23 
8.  Whistleblowers with first-hand knowledge of Luceros admissions prac-
24 
tices have now come forward. They report that, under the guise of holistic review, 
25 
26  Geffen requires applicants to submit responses that are intended to allow the Com-
27 
mittee to glean the applicants race, which the medical school later confirms via 
28 
  4 
 

Case 2:25-cv-04131     Document 1     Filed 05/08/25     Page 5 of 38   Page ID #:5
 
1  interviews. Lucero and her handpicked committee members routinely and openly dis-
2 
cuss race (and racial proxies) and use race as a factor to make admission decisions. 
3 
Lucero berates and belittles committee members who raise concerns about admitting 
4 
5  minority students because of their race despite low GPAs and MCAT scores. At UCLA 
6 
Medical School, race is not only a factor but often decisiveabove GPA and MCAT 
7 
scoresin making admission decisions.  
8 
9.  The numbers show that UCLA is engaged in intentional racial balancing. 
9 
10 
Between 2020 and 2023, the percentage of white and Asian applicants to Geffen was 
11 
consistently around 73% of the total applicant pool. Yet the percentage of matriculants 
12 
to Geffen who are white and Asian plummeted: 65.7% in 2020, 57.1% in 2021, 57.8% 
13 
14  in 2022, and 53.7% in 2023. 
15 
10.  UCLA has withheld key admissions data from the public and its own 
16 
internal oversight body. UCLA has also effectively shut down its own internal probe 
17 
18  into its admissions practices by insisting on non-disclosure agreements from the par-
19 
ticipants in the admissions process. Geffens apparent illegal use of race has even 
20 
prompted the U.S. Department of Health and Human Services to begin an investiga-
21 
22  tion into its admissions practices.  
23
